bibl.title: Case history of David Manrique by Roberto Serpa, translated by Frederick A. Miller, [1923]

div1.p: The case history describes Manrique's final illness and his autopsy.

div1.head: Case history of David Manrique by Roberto Serpa, translated by Frederick A. Miller, [1923]
div1.p:
David Manrique, 52 years of age, citizen of Onzaga and lived in
Rionegro for more than eight years where he was employed as a farm laborer.

In past years had been a patient in the hospital in Bucaramanga
on account of some nervous disease undetermined. He had suffered from fre-
quent diarrheas. He took intoxicating liquors in excess and was accustomed
to become drunk about every eight days. He lived on an hacienda named
“Las Quebradas” distant from Rionegro four hours or twelve miles, this
hacienda being the closest to the town.

On the 30th of July, he arrived from the hacienda and stayed in the
house until 7.p.m. and then went to the street returning at 8 p.m. on account
of having felt symptoms of diarrhea. On the 31st. he felt better and went
again to the street occupied in normal occupation; during the day he was seen
to take “aguardiente” (native brandy) and “guarapo”. He went to bed at 8 p.m.
feeling a little indisposed. He awoke at 10 p.m. with great pain in the
abdomen, nausea, vomiting, great pain in the hips and diarrhea. The vomiting
and the diarrhea were normal in color and he thought it was one of the usual
attacks of diarrhea. The vomiting and the diarrhea continued, the diarrhea
becoming bloody and the vomiting at first yellow, then red and then black at
the same time the abdominal pains increased as well as those of the hips. At
this time patient could not urinate.

On the 2nd. of August this office was notified of the condition of
the patient. He was sent to the hospital immediately and the physical examina-
tion showed: Face anxious, respirations shallow, great pain in the abdomen,
restlessness, and great pain in the epigastric region on palpation. Pulse
thready, imperceptible, temperature 39 1/2 C.

From time to time the patient vomited material the color of
“cafecon leche”. The stools were abundant and bloody. A sound was passed
2
to secure urine and the bladder found completely empty. At that time was
prescribed small doses of solution of Sodium Bicarbonate 3%.

On the 3rd. of August at 3.30 p.m. an autopsy was performed and
showed the following: the tissues very slightly subicteric with post mortem
ecchimomtic spots. The subcutaneous tissue showed a yellow tint a little
more pronounced than normal. The mucosa of the lips and gums showed haemorrhagic
spots. On opening the abdominal cavity the intestines were seen to be dilated
and congested in their whole extent, with all the vessels visible and of a
dark red color, bathed in a transudate haematic or peritoneal fluid.

The contents of the stomach were of a dark grey color and the
mucosa showed many plaques ecchimotic in the cardiac region, haemorrhagic
points along the greater and lesser curvatures and ecchimotic plaques in the
pyloric region. Liver greatly congested of the color of red wine and with
some spots a little darker. Some parts of the liver were harder than the
normal liver and others softer so that one could press their finger into it.
The liver bled on section. The gall bladder was one and one half times
normal size and contained a great amount of normal bile; thirteen gall stones
of the size of a grain of corn were found but none in the ducts. SPLEEN normal.
KIDNEYS congested but of normal size with haemorrhagic points on the surface.
The parenchyma more congested and blood flowed on section. The BLADDER re-
tracted and doubled and the pubis was completely empty. The LUNGS normal,
The HEART normal in size, congested and the ventricules contained liquid
blood. It was noted that the blood was more fluid and less viscous than
normal.
Translated from the report of Dr. Roberto Serpa
